titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Intelsat Agreement Negotiating History Records, 1961-1998 MS2186
titlestmt.author: University Archives, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-01-18 11:59:30 -0500.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: This collection focuses on documenting the negotiating history behind the formation and governance of INTELSAT, the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization. Included are documents used in actual meetings, conferences, and working groups, correspondence both internal and external, drafts of various governing documents, technical reports, and position papers of the various countries involved, and finally the official intergovernmental agreements. Also included are vertical files from each election for the position of Director General. Material in the collection dates from 1961-1998, with the majority of the negotiating history records being from 1968-1971. Some of the correspondence and documents have indexes, which are filed at the beginning of each series when present.
did.physloc: Materials may be stored off-site, and may require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of Collection
arrangement.p: Organized into 7 series: Conference documents, Correspondence, Position papers, Draft agreements, Final documents, Vertical files, Directors' General, and Technical reports

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains documents used in actual meetings, conferences, and working groups, correspondence both internal and external, drafts of various governing documents, technical reports, and position papers of the various countries involved, and finally the official intergovernmental agreements. Also included are vertical files from each election for the position of Director General. Included in the directors' general vertical files is information regarding the dismissal of director Richard Colino. Some of the correspondence and documents have indexes, which are filed at the beginning of each series when present. This collection focuses on documenting the negotiating history behind the formation and governance of INTELSAT, the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization. Dates of the collection are from 1961-1998, though the bulk of this collection dates from 1968-1971, during the negotiations for the definitive agreements of the member nations.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This collection was originally gathered through the efforts of John B. Gantt, lead attorney involved in the negotiating process, and William English, a communications scientist and member of the board of COMSAT, the United States Satellite governing body.
It is unknown who donated this collection to the University and in what year.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The International Telecommunications Satellite Consortium (Intelsat) was an international organization formed to oversee international satellite communication. Intelsat mangaed communication satellites that provided international broadcast services. The intergovernmental organization began on August 20, 1964 with 11 participating countries. Intelsat's first satellite went into orbit in 1965 and at the time had eleven particpating countries. By 1973, Intelsat had grown to more than 80 countries. In 1971 these 80 countries finally reach an agreement to broaden control of the world's communication satellite system. The INTELSAT Definitive Agreement entered into force on February 12, 1973. Prior to this landmark agreement the United States had been running Intelsat. This agreement provided the United States, represented by Communication Satellite Corp (Comsat), will remain the dominant power in Intelsat. Also, in this agreement no one country will control more than 40% of the votes of the Board of Governors. Intelsat will convene an assembly where all member nations will have equal voices.

By 2001, Intelsat became a private company with the primary source of revenue comign from satellite usage fees. The Intelsat system enables Internet connection, television broadcasting, cellular telephony, and corporate network services.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains documents used in actual meetings, plenipotentiary conferences, working groups, and including press releases and agenda. The material dates from 1969-1971 and includes material from the all the committees, negotiating conferences, and intersessional working groups. Beginning with a selected list of conference documents, numbered in their original order, then materials from the committee meetings: Structure and Function, Legal, Financial, and Operational.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series begins with an chronological index for the correspondence. Material dates from 1961-1971. Included are many internal communications from the Communications Satellite Corp. (COMSAT), also included are communications to and with the U.S. Department of State. Correspondents include among others, John B. Gantt (Hunton and Williams, LLC), William D. English, Ambassador Abbott Washburn, (chair of the US delegation), Joseph Charyk (President, COMSAT), Richard Mizrack, David Acheson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this series the"By Subject" position papers are arranged alphabetically by the major topics of discussion throughout the conference negotiations. These topics include Accession, Board of Governors, Membership, and Liability and Legal issues. "By country" position papers contain information on how each country contributed to the negotiations, issues, and how they voted on issues. Most of this intelligence was gathered by COMSAT, the United States satellite governing body, and these materials date from 1968-1971 (and undated). Please note that country labels reflect nation names from that time period.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in 2 subseries: Subject position papers and Country position papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this subseries the "By Subject" position cover the major topics of discussion throughout the conference negotiations. These topics include Accession, Board of Governors, Membership, and Liability and Legal issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains various drafts of the agreements or portions of the agreements, some with handwritten markups. The series is divided into the Operating Agreement drafts, and the Intergovernmental Agreement drafts. Material dates from 1968-1971. One legal-size folder, an Intergovernmental Agreement draft dated February 3, 1970, has been transferred to Box 33 due to its size.

did.unittitle: Intergovernmental Agreement drafts February-March 1970 (additional oversize folder)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in original order of definitive arrangements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes final agreements, often referred to as "definitive arrangements" for INTELSAT, as well as associated annex documents, operating agreements, and related meeting notes.

did.unittitle: 1964 Agreement Establishing Interim Arrangements for a Global Commercial Communications Satellite System and Special Agreement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes documents relating to election procedures for the Director General of INTELSAT (also called Secretary General, also called Inspector General), including election regulations, voting records, and notes. Materials date from 1970-1998, and cover the directorships of Santiago Astrain, Richard Colino, dean Burch, Irving Goldstein, and Conny Kullman. Also included are materials related to campaigns for director, including biographies, correspondence. For some directors, materials from their adminstration is also included, such as speeches or notes of thanks. Also included are materials relating to the dismissal of Richard Colino and related lawsuit.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged by committee or meeting where a technical report was created.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains technical documents, sometimes referred to as "annexes" in paper descriptions and indexes of the collection; these materials, dating 1968-1971, relate to the technical reports and findings produced by the various panels created during the negotiation process. Included are documents relating to technical issues, financial issues, and marketing plans. These are organized by the committee or working group that prepared them.

There were four major meetings of the Preparatory Committee, I, II, III, and IV, and most of the documents were products of one of these meetings. Other documents come from intersessional meetings or independent working group panels. Some groups provided indexes of documents, others did not. In some cases, document numbers or portions of documents may be missing or incomplete.
